@snleee Thanks for bringing up the concern. Although I would be surprised if these versions of Thrift generates incompatible code for same input, I did go ahead and test the scenario you mentioned and it works as expected.

> @kishoreg sorry about the delay in responses on my end as I am traveling.
> 
> Can you elaborate on what you mean by guaranteeing the latency numbers? Unless these are measured, there isn't a way to guarantee them, right? Once the numbers are available, Pinot operators can make appropriate changes to improve the system.

What I meant is the name SLOConfig gives the impression that we will guarantee the latency somehow. Its like qps or quota config. My suggestion is to rename the config to something like log_slow_queries and slow_query_threshold. MySQL provides some config variables like this.
 
> Client side measurements include noise (network and other client side induced latency) and are not reliable measures.

I was referring to pinot client. Typically, network issues are also part of the SLA.

> The config helps emit the base metrics that are can be reliably used in measuring availability numbers from server side. Many services at LinkedIn use server side measurements - we have been emitting these currently from the broker using Jetty/container configs - but they make per table metrics harder to compute (as broker multi-tenancy is common).

That sounds good. Please rename SLOConfig to something else.

@icefury71 Good questions. I don't have a good answer. Let's create a separate issue on how to use presence vectors in the query execution layer. At a high level, there are 3 possible options
- users explicitly specify the predicate in the query.
- Pinot implicitly updates the where clause appropriately based on the query
- Pinot passes the presence vectors to the aggregation functions so that each function can handle it appropriately.

For now, let us focus on supporting 1. we can start design discussion for  2/3

Get travis working with both Kafka 0.9 and 2.0.

Still requires manually click to rerun failed jobs then it will pass.

> 1. Please open issues for things not handled in the PR.
Will create issues for
- supporting map type syntax map['key']. This will be handled automatically when we start using calcite.
Anything else you can think of?
> 2. The __KEYS and __VALUES columns have specific semantics in the code, however, they are stored as MV columns. Are there any issues in allowing these columns to be treated as regular MV columns when the queries are not of the form specified in the PR description?
Not really.
> 3. Would be good to add a real world example that this feature can help solve, in the description.
- will update the docs. I think the need for map type is pretty obvious.  classic cases - tags/labels, sparse dimensions, etc.


-

PR https://github.com/apache/incubator-pinot/pull/4445 abstracted Kafka connector into a runtime dependency. 

PR #4397  implements Kafka 2.0 connectors and make the build and release to use different profiles. 
By default, still include kafka 0.9 and users could use `-Dkafka.version=2.0` to include Kafka 2.0 instead of Kafka 0.9.

The latest changes have the following:

(1) Entry point in pinot-admin tool for table rebalancer
(2) Add a cluster integration test for the end-to-end path for the usage from pinot-admin tool

If this work-around indeed fixes the issue, we should code this up in the controller starter and enable it using configuration so that it can be used in production if needed. The configuration can be very specific (e.g. "workaround_helix_331") so that we can drop the config once the bug is fixed.
@Jackie-Jiang Hi Jackie can you review this part of the code? Seems you implemented the counter. Thanks.

The 2 integration test scenarios added in TestRebalancerAdminToolClusterIntegrationTest have also been exercised manually by halting the test and running rebalancer via sh pinot-admin.sh RebalanceTable command.
cc @Jackie-Jiang , @snleee , @mcvsubbu

Thanks for fixing this. What is the root cause? Do we still face this problem if the data is late ?

> Thanks for fixing this. What is the root cause? Do we still face this problem if the data is late ?

If the data is late, the front end will show a dash, which means the data is not available, instead of showing a wrong number. 

This bug is caused by both frontend and backend. The frontend time range selector sometimes returns  misaligned time stamps. The time zone alignments in the endpoint also round the time stamp to the wrong direction.
